div.p: 1. V:30. Tuesday.

Mr Davis came on with my Son from Boston, and called here this morning. He and Charles rode with me to the Capitol— I introduced them into the library. H.R.U.S. The duelling report came up. Half the members absent at the race-course. May of Illinois moved on adjournment—rejected by yeas and nays 7 to 156— Duncan had moved to strike out from my motion the words the paper purporting to be (the report) I agreed to their being struck out— Various motions made for amending the Instructions. It was agreed to take the questions separately on the commitment and each branch of the Instructions, when Thomas moved to strike out the second branch of the Instructions—which was carried 96 to 68.— And then Thomas moved to strike out the other part of the Instructions, avowing that after that there will be no motive for recommitment— Then Rariden moved a substitute for my Resolution, to which Mercer moved an Amendment requiring the Committee to report a Bill to prevent the practices of duelling, all which I accepted, instead of my Resolution—whereupon Toucey asked leave to report the Bill from the Senate with amendments, which was admitted by unanimous consent. The Bill and Amendments were referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— I ordered to be printed— Legaré declared himself against the Bill, and defended the practice of duelling— Bell made a speech against all the proceedings of the House in this case, questioning the power of the House, but he was arrested by the Speaker as out of order.— Chambers of Kentucky made a bitter Speech against the proceedings of the Committee— Sherrod Williams moved a reconsideration of the vote rejecting the second Instructions to be given on recommitting the report— Boon made the point that there was no Quorum in the House— I moved a call—rejected by 60 to 68 showing a Quorum, no sooner found than it was gone again. Three several motions were made to adjourn—twice rejected by yeas and nays, at my call— Yell proposed to set aside the duel and take up the army Bill; but a third motion to adjourn was made and carried 78 to 56. before three O’Clock. The members were all gone to the Horse-Race— Coming home I met G. Kemble, returning from the race— T. K. Davis dined with us.— Mr Frye and A. Kemble were here in the Evening— Mrs Adams and Mary went to the Theatre, and Charles and I to the Birth-night Ball of Mr Pontois, the French Minister— We went early, about 9. and came home before 11. Company large—crowd great— Apartments small almost the whole Senate there— Many members of the House— Executive Officers, Heads of Departments, Clerks, private Citizens and Strangers— There was dancing and a supper, and the party broke up about 3. of the morning.
2. V:30. Wednesday

Owing to the labours or the pleasures of yesterday, my Catarrhal cough was this day much worse— H.R.U.S. The motion of Sherrod Williams to reconsider the vote to strike out the Resolution to discharge the Committee from the further consideration of the question of the breach of privileges of the House, and of the Petitions and Memorials Connor moved a call of the House, upon which after much consumption of time only 180 members were found present— The question of reconsideration was variously debated— M’Kennon offered a substitute for both my Resolutions of Instructions, but afterwards withdrew it— The question of reconsideration returned; and I spoke perhaps an hour and a half, and exposed the course pursued by Thomas to evade the manifest purpose of the House, by indirection; and I denounced the whole proceeding as an administration measure, entirely one sided and partial, which brought up all the bile of Thomas, and of Boon of Indiana, and they poured it forth in fury— Thomas repeatedly interrupted me and got in peppery Speeches, under colour of explanation Boon impertinently intruded upon the debate, and I got a general laugh of the House upon him, by saying that they surely could not understand me as referring to him, fair, candid, and impartial as they had daily opportunities of observing him to be, when I charged this proceeding with the reverse of all these qualities— Upon the laugh, Boon turned pale as a ghost, came round opposite where I was speaking— Stared me in the face while I was speaking, as if he thought he could brow-beat me— I looked him occasionally in the face, with cool indifference, and went on— When Thomas had finished his reply, Boon snarled out his rage in scurrilities for which he was called to order by the House, and the Speaker, though I intreated that he might be permitted to proceed— Murray of Kentucky moved to lay the whole subject on the table; rejected by yeas and nays 47 to 124.— The motion to reconsider the vote of yesterday, to strike out the Instructions moved by Pickens and accepted by me, was rejected by yeas and nays 82 to 90— Then came the question, upon my first instructions, as modified by the motion of Rariden, accepted by me— The clause moved by Mercer, requiring the Committee to report an Anti-duelling bill, fell of course, by Toucey’s Report yesterday of the Bill from the Senate with Amendments— The vote against Thomas’s motion to strike out the instruction was by yeas and nays 93 to 82.— Fletcher of Vermont then moved an amendment, requiring the Committee to report again upon the petitions, and memorials— Slade moved an amendment to this which was rejected— Fletcher’s amendment was carried by yeas and nays 89 to 86— Arphaxad Loomis moved an amendment, requiring the Committee to strike out from their report all that required punishment of members of the House— I frightened him out of it by approving it,
it; and he changed it for an amendment, excepting the question of the breach of privilege from the instruction to strike out the argumentative parts— Reed moved as an amendment to this, that if any member of the house should prove involved, the Committee should report the facts specially without measures of punishment— After some debate on the amendments there were sundry motions to adjourn, and one call of the House rejected by yeas and nays, one by the casting vote of the Speaker 88 to 88—after which, past 5. O’Clock a motion was carried without yeas and nays to adjourn— On reaching home I found that Charles’s wife and daughter had arrived from Baltimore— Dawson of Georgia, told me in the House jokingly, that he had had thoughts of interposing between me and Boon, to restore the equality— But as I was coming out of the Capital, a man who announced himself to me as an old acquaintance, by the name of Coll. Knight said he had something confidential to say to me, and took me aside, and with a solemn look, advised me to be upon my guard, for that Coll. Boon, at whose lodgings I understood him to say that he was a boarder, was a high tempered and violent man; and might perhaps attack me personally— He said that Boon had already been much offended at some quotation made by me in the house, but he did not tell me what it was— I simply answered, that I was obliged to him; and that it was well— I have had many such notices, which I have always despised— May these repeated warnings at least preserve me from giving any just cause of offence, without deterring me from any proper exercise of the freedom of Speech— I visited President Van Buren this morning with my Son.
3. VI. Thursday.

My Cough returned severely last Night, and I thought I should be unable to attend in the House this day; but found myself much better again this morning; though with the Cough obstinately clinging to me— I attended at the Committee room of the Manufactures; but only Tillinghast, Vail and Webster were there, and we formed No Quorum— H.R.U.S.— Three Messages from the President were read, two of which were referred to the Committee of foreign Affairs— One of them was with a Note of the Mexican Minister concerning the affair of the Steamboat— The other concerning the claim of Territory on the borders of the South Sea— The consideration of this at Cushing’s motion was postponed to this day week— Bell of Tennessee moved to suspend the rules to admit a motion, that when the House should adjourn it should be till next Monday, for time to cleanse the hall, and put down the matting, for the Summer arrangement— The concert of operation was strong, so as to prevent the yeas and nays being taken—the rules were suspended, and the
the Resolution to adjourn over adopted— Whereupon Mr Bell immediately moved to adjourn— He suspended the motion at my request, until I had by leave reported from the Committee of Manufactures, the Bill from the Senate N 175. to refund to the Georgia Rail-road and Banking company certain duties paid on the importation of Spikes— It was at my motion referred to the Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union, and ordered to be printed for which Mr Dawson of Georgia came to my Seat, and thanked me— Adjourned before Noon— Mr Preston, the Senator from South Carolina introduced to me, his mother, his daughter and his Sister in the Hall which they were visiting, after the adjournment of the House— As I was returning home, I met in the capitol yard Alexander H. Everett who was going the House— He turned about and walked with me to my door conversing chiefly upon, a project which he is meditating of setting up a Newspaper in Boston to support the present Administration of the United States, on a different platform from that of the Advocate or that of the Morning Post— He seemed to think that T. K. Davis and my Son, were disposed to engage in this undertaking; but as to Charles at least was mistaken. I thought it altogether impracticable; and knew not what part of the political system of the present administration could be supported upon any sound principle— At home, the remainder of the day— My wife ill this Evening— Mrs Stewart was here— Giusta.
4. V:15. Friday.

North-east storm— Rain at intervals throughout the day, and Evening— I had agreed to go with Mrs Charles to the race; but the weather was so bad that we gave it up— My wife and Mary went and visited Johnson Hellen who is confined to his bed—dangerously ill— I called at the Pension Office, at the request by Letter of Lizur B. Canfield of Homer, Cortland County, New-York addressed to me and to Daniel Webster, to certify to the Commissioners of Pensions James L. Edwards, that Daniel Weed is a Justice of Peace, and L. W. Clark (Lucius W. Clarke) Pastor of the second Church in Amesbury, Massachusetts These certificates are requested to substantiate a Pension claim of Rhoda Pressey, widow of Benjamin Pressey under the act of 7. June 1832. Mr Edwards found the papers, forwarded to him by Mr Canfield, and promised to report to me on the case— I then called at the Department of State, to ask a Passport for Mr Edward Cruft who is going to Europe, and had sent me a description of his person— The Secretary, Mr Forsyth was at the President’s, but Mr Dayton the Chief Clerk took the description of the person, and sent me the Passport this Evening— While there I enquired for the manuscript list of Documents, made out for Horace Everett, to indicate which of them he
he would wish to have sent, in answer to his call— After consulting with me, he demanded the whole— A few days since, a very small part of them were sent, with a statement that it would take some time to have translations made of many of the others— Mr Dayton at my request shewed me the list, and in answer to my enquiry when they would be ready to be sent to the House, said, in three or four weeks— I looked carefully over the list, and believe all the correspondence with Mexico is there— I found particularly the Letter, from Coll. Anthony Butler to Mr Forsyth of 17. June 1835. which Forsyth’s answer to it, of 2d. July 1835. already communicated, had excited in me a strong curiosity to see. I thence went to Mr Pettrich’s Sculptor Study, but he was not there; and then to the Wigwam where I saw Mr Catlin’s Gallery of Indian Portraits, and Museum. He wishes to sell it to Congress, but talks of taking it to England— The Portraits have no merit as works of art— The War-dances and Council fires are caricatures of disgusting nature— The views on the Missouri river from 1200 to 1900 miles above St. Louis are very indifferent landscapes, and the buffaloes hunted by wolves, are not comparable to Snyder’s’ Boar hunting.— The collection is perhaps valuable as unique— Mr Catlin was not there— As I was walking home I was overtaken by Antoine, who walked with me— He had called on me yesterday, and told me he was going to Europe for a few Months to visit his wife’s relations in England, and his own in Piedmont—perhaps to make arrangements for his final return to his native Country— I kept house the rest of the day— My wife still much indisposed.
5. V:30. Saturday.

Visitors all day— Mr Pettrich just after breakfast; having heard that I had been at his Study came to apologise for his absence at the time, and to invite a repetition of the visit, which I accordingly made with Charles and T. K. Davis. His best work there is a bust of Commodore Rodgers— Those of President Van Buren and Mr Clay are inferior as likenesses, and too much idealized— The Group of Charity, the boy holding a baptismal font—the sleeping innocence with a lamb sleeping between her arm and side—the angling girl, I had seen before— There was a bust of Black Hawk, and another Indian Chief in Chocolate coloured clay, which Mr Pettrich said he should send to Thorwaldsen at Rome— The walls of the Study are covered with outline sketches in black paint. Portraits of Indian Chiefs who have recently been, or are now here— Davis preferred these to the Sculpture; and they are more aboriginal in their character— The busts differ little from those of hard featured, and pain befurrowed white faces— His Black Hawk closely resembles the
the face on antient Statues and coins of the Roman Emperor Vitellius— I returned from the workshop home— Mr William Colgate is a manufacturer of Starch, who came to enquire, of the probable fate of a Petition referred to the Committee of Manufactures, for a repeal of the duty upon wheat, or the laying of a duty upon Starch— The duty upon wheat is 25 cents a bushel. Starch is duty free— The consequence is that all the Starch making establishments in this Country except his own are suspended—the Starch being imported from Bremen— I invited Mr Colgate to attend the Meeting of the Committee of manufactures next Monday Morning and to present his views and statements to them, but he said he wished to leave the City this afternoon— I told him I would then report to the Committee the substance of his remarks to me— But that there was the whole farming interest against repealing the duty upon wheat, and the whole anti-tariff interest against laying the duty upon Starch, so that I doubted whether so late in the Session, it would be possible to carry either alternative through both Houses of Congress.— Mr Briggs came and introduced Mr Pomeroy one of his Constituents from Springfield—and General Daniel Parker his Son, a boy about 12 years old— Mr Edward Blackburn, is a travelling agent of the House of George and Robert Blackburn, Wine Merchants at Madeira— Mr Frye was here, and took with him the two Deeds with the three plans of the land at the Columbia Mills. Campbell and Thomas B. J. Frye dined with us— Charles and his wife with T. K. Davis dined at the President’s— Mrs W. S. Smith spent the Evening here—Backgammon. My time was absorbed, so that I could barely answer Letters from O. Bacheler—
6. V:30. Sunday.

I took my Granddaughter Mary Louisa with me to the Presbyterian Church and heard a stranger from Isaiah 55.2. “Wherefore do ye spend money for that which is not bread? and your labour for that which satisfieth not? hearken diligently unto me, and eat ye that which is good, and let your soul delight itself in fatness.” The inference drawn by the preacher from this text was that Man was a reasonable creature, and that it was surprizing how little regard to reason was discoverable his conduct—and then he came back in conclusion upon the depravity of man, and the atonement— Is not the doctrine itself of the depravity of man and the atonement a proof that man is not a rational being? Is not inconsistency a summary of the human character— If I am utterly depraved what is the use of preaching to me? If I am utterly depraved, how can I blame my neighbour for being so too? And if regeneration is the test of Salvation, must it not be because the new man is better than the old?— Charles and T. K. Davis were also there— The preacher gave notice of a Meeting to-morrow evening, to devise means, for the future support of the Pastor— We were overtaken
overtaken by a cold shower returning home. T. K. Davis dined with us— After dinner I attended alone at St. John’s Church, where Mr Hawley read the service for the third Sunday after Easter, and preached from Isaiah 52.7. “How beautiful upon the Mountains, are the feet of him that bringeth good tidings, that publisheth peace; that bringeth good tidings of good, that publisheth salvation: that saith unto Zion, thy God reigneth!” The text above is worth a hundred Sermons— Campbell was here this Evening, and Hull and he played on the Piano and sung Psalms— Visits also, from Mrs Tudor and her daughter Mrs Stewart; and from Mr W. S. Smith— I consumed much of the day in extracting minutes from father Louis Hennepin’s first publication of his exploring expedition upon the Mississippi with La Salle—printed 5. January 1683.
7. V:30. Monday.

Attended at the room of the Committee of Manufactures— Met there Tillinghast, Vail and Webster— Absent, Biddle, Foster, Hunter, Naylor, Slade— No Quorum; and no business could be done— I informed the members present of the visit I had received on Saturday from Mr Colgate; and of his conversation with me; and the Memorial from the Starch-makers of Philadelphia was read again— It was agreed that the Starch makers had reason to complain that with a duty of 25 cents a bushel on wheat; and of 50 cents to a 100 lb of flour, Starch is admitted duty free— But the Philadelphia Memorials ask a duty of 7 cents a lb which is at least 100 per Cent of the value— Mr Vail observed that the principal use of Starch was in manufactures of Cotton and Linen, and that the manufacturers of those Articles would earnestly resist the imposition of any duty upon Starch— H.R.U.S. I found the House in Session, and sundry members rising successively and presenting Petitions, Memorials and Resolutions, which were received and acted upon without opposition— I said I had also a few Petitions to present for which I asked leave— Objection was immediately made— I knew it would be in vain to ask a suspension of the rules—another member immediately asked leave to present a petition, to which I objected, and gave notice that I should object to the reception of any such motion, while the indulgences yielded to other members were denied to me— Cambreleng moved a suspension of the Rules, to take up the Bills, referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Lost by yeas and nays 112 to 57. close upon two to one. He then moved a suspension of the Rules to take up the Treasury Note— Bill— Lost 102 to 77. not near two thirds— The Speaker announced the unfinished business, the report of the duel Committee— The question was on an amendment moved by John Reed, to an amendment moved by Arphaxad Loomis to the instructions on recommitment of the report proposed by me— Reed’s amendment was that if a member of the House should prove involved, in the breach of privilege, the Committee should not proceed against
against him, but report that fact to the House. Sawyer of North-Carolina, after a short Speech, moved to lay the whole subject on the table. This after some discussion was lost 48 to 131. Reed’s motion was debated till Rives moved to postpone the whole subject till the first of June; which after some discussion he withdrew, at the earnest supplication of Bynum whose name had at last got implicated in the debate— Rariden had announced his intention to move another Resolution instructing the Committee to report upon the part taken in the duel by Duncan and Bynum— This threw them into an ungovernable frenzy; but Rariden’s motion not being in order the question was taken upon Reeds amendment which was rejected 79 to 82— The question coming back upon Loomis’s amendment, Sibley moved an amendment to it instructing the Committee to report the names of all the members of the House concerned in the duel— Loomis accepted Sibley’s amendment as a modification of his own; but it brought off the steam from Bynum and Duncan— Dawson had moved to lay the whole subject on the table, and to print the Journal and evidence— Briggs called for a division of the question and the House refused to lay on the table 56 to 103.— At this motion of Sibley’s hastily accepted by Loomis, but under which the agonies of Bynum and Duncan were convulsive Thomas became alarmed, and moved to lay the whole subject on the table; and to print all the papers. He came in thus a second time at a dead lift, and rallied the party with all his powers; but his motion was divided, and that for laying on the table was lost 73 to 95. About half the administration rank and file voting for and half against the motion— Sibley then replied with Spirit to Bynum and Duncan—and pressed Toucey so hard upon his vote to recommit the Petitions. and Memorials, that Toucey declared he had voted for it, for the express purpose of defeating the recommitment— Underwood and Bynum took the floor together— Bynum full charged to reply to Sibley.— But after several struggles, and refusals to adjourn a motion for it was carried about 6 o’Clock by yeas and nays 82 to 75. When I returned home, I found the family at dinner Mrs Frye dining with them.— Mr T. K. Davis came in soon after— Then Campbell with a young man named Smith— After that W. S. Smith, and finally Mr Frye. We had music singing with the Piano— Joshua L. Martin of Alabama, told me that his colleague Lawler was at the point of death.
8. V:30. Tuesday

At the door of the Capitol before I entered the Hall of the House of Representatives this morning, I was informed of the death of Joab Lawler, a member of the House from the State of Alabama— At the meeting of the House, immediately after the reading of the Journal, the event was announced byLyon, another of the members from the State, with an appropriate obituary eulogy and the usual resolutions of attendance at his funeral to-morrow, and for wearing crape—after which the House immediately adjourned— I left in the Clerk’s room a Letter of introduction for Mr
Mr F. O. J. Smith to Daniel Brent, our Consul at Paris— Returning home I stopped at the National Intelligencer Office, and took, for revisal the minutes by the Reporters Stansbury and Otis of my Speeches of 30. April and 1. May, on the Duel Committee Reports— The minutes are still incomplete— After dinner Mrs. Adams, with Mary, Charles and his wife went to see Mr T. B. Johnson living with Kervand at Georgetown; and we all spent the Evening at Mr W. S. Smith’s.— I received this Evening printed copies of three sets of Resolutions, adopted by the Legislature of Massachusetts, one of 16. March 1838. against the annexation of Texas to the United States, one of 30 March against the Sub-Treasury, and one of 4. April 1838 for an anti-duelling bill— They are enclosed under a cover sealed with the Seal of the Executive Council of the State; but without any Letter, or sign manual— I had called this morning at the Pension Office, with a Letter from S. A. Turner of Scituate, concerning a claim for bounty Lands for a man named Newell, a disabled Soldier of the late War— I left the papers with Mr Edwards, who promised me a report upon them— I called also at the Office of Mr Ragsdale of the Navy Department, who had written a note to me requesting the meaning of the word payments, in a Resolution of the House moved by me, calling for certain documents— I told him my meaning of the word payments, and noted it signed with the initials of my name, on his own Letter which I left with him.
9. V. Wednesday.

Funeral of Joab Lawler.— I called at the Office of the National Intelligencer for the remaining notes taken by the Reporters of my Speeches in the House last week, upon the duel Committee’s Reports— They sent me afterwards to the House the Notes which had been admitted— The House met at Noon, and the usual ceremonies were performed— The Chaplain of the Senate read part of the episcopal funeral service, and made a prayer— Mr Reese the Chaplain of the House delivered a discourse, honorary to the deceased, who had himself been a clergyman— The usual procession to the cemetery near the Navy Yard was then made— I rode with N. B. Borden of Massachusetts, John Edwards of New-York, and Edward Davies of Pennsylvania— We had an indifferent Carriage, and Mr Borden and Mr. Davies found another conveyance back to the Capitol. I got back to the Hall just in time to hear Rice Garland move the adjournment of the House, the Speaker being in the Chair, and two other members present— I had given Mr Rives of Virginia, a check from my Son on the Merchant’s Bank Boston, for which he is to give me an order on the Serjeant at Arms of the House— Mr Owens of Georgia had asked to introduce to me a Mr Howard, employed by that State to go to England, to procure certain records relating to the History of Georgia— And he asked for him a Letter of introduction which I promised— After returning home the rest of the day was consumed in revising the Notes of the Reporters and supplying their deficiencies— I
I had borrowed from the Congress Library, the Volume of Gibbon’s Memoirs of his own Life and Writings, containing his account of his Representation in Parliament of the borough of Leskeard— Stansbury had made wretched work of my allusion to this passage in Gibbon’s Memoirs, and I wished to be strictly accurate in rectifying his Notes— I supplied also the omission of my remarks on the morning of last Wednesday—which occupied this Evening— Charles and his wife, and Mary went to a party at Mr Gilpin’s— We had also been invited; but I could not prevail upon myself to go.
10. V. Thursday.

Called at the Office of the National Intelligencer, and left with Mr Gales the minutes of the Reporters Otis and Stansbury, of my Speeches of 30. April and 1. and 2. May, revised by me— Attended the Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures. Present Adams, Slade, Tillinghast, Vail, Webster— Hunter had been at the chamber, minuted his name as present and then gone away. Absent Biddle, Foster and Naylor— I obtained a direction from the Committee to report to the House the Senate’s Bill 176. for refunding certain duties to a New-York Railroad Company, without amendment— H.R.U.S. immediately after the reading of the Journal a Message from the President was received with a Report from the Secretary of the Treasury urging the extreme necessity of the immediate necessity for the passage of the Treasury Note-Bill. Mr Cambreleng gave notice that when the Report of the duel Committee should be disposed of, as he trusted it would this day, he should move to take up the Treasury Note Bill to-morrow Morning.— After some abortive attempts for a call of the House, Underwood made a speech, utterly denying the right of the House to institute any enquiry into a duel for the purpose of censure upon any of its members— The Speaker arrested him at the threshold of this argument, as out of order— Underwood insisted. The Speaker became peremptory— Underwood appealed from the decision, and reduced his point to writing— The Speaker then said, the Gentleman from Kentucky had narrowed down his claim to discuss the right, so much that he might proceed, whereupon Underwood for about an hour took a range of argument against the power of the House to institute any such investigation, and that there had been no violation of the privileges of the House, whatever.— As he was drawing to a conclusion, Mr Owens of Georgia took me into the lobby of the House and introduced to me, the Revd. Charles Wallace Howard, who presented me a recommendatory Letter from Governor Gilmer. Mr Howard is going to England, to procure copies of documents relating to the Settlement and History of Georgia at the Colonial Office; and also a Library and apparatus for Oglethorpe University— Mr Owens had asked of me, a Letter for him to Mr Rush, which
which I promised to give him. He said he was at Gadsby’s; and should go to-morrow Morning for New-York, there to embark on the 11th for England— On returning into the House I found Thomas speaking with great fervour and finally concluding with the same motion he had lost last week— To lay all the Reports and documents of the duel Committee on the Table, and print them—not naming the Journal— The motion was not debateable— But a division was called— The motion to lay on the table was carried by yeas and nays 102 to 76 almost every administration member voting for it— Then came the question upon the printing, which I required should be put as it was entered on the minutes of the Journal— The Speaker refused this, saying that the Clerk’s entries were only private minutes, and not the Journal of the House— Petriken moved the previous question upon the printing, which the Speaker decided would be in order; although only half the motion had been decided—before that, the main question, would have been upon the Resolutions reported by the Committee— But the report, being laid on the table, the main question would now be on the printing— Rice Garland moved a reconsideration of the vote to lay on the table— Thomas objected that the motion to reconsider could not be made, till the vote should be taken on his whole Resolution; and the Speaker so decided— Rice Garland then appealed from the Speaker’s decision; but afterwards withdrew his appeal and the motion to reconsider. I renewed the appeal, but the Speaker decided that Garland having withdrawn his motion to reconsider I could neither renew the appeal nor the motion to reconsider, as I had voted against laying on the table— The question upon the printing was then divided and taken first on the three reports carried 123 to 74 and then on the evidence and journal 189 to 4. I voted for the printing on both questions— I then enquired of the Speaker what would be the effect of moving a reconsideration; he said it would be upon each of the questions separately taken, and not upon the whole— This decision seemed to me absurdly inconsistent with the previous decision that a reconsideration of the first vote could not be moved; till after the subsequent votes on a divided resolution— For if the reconsideration of one part of the whole resolution could not affect the other questions on the same motion, there is no reason why it should not be moved immediately after the taking the vote— But all this had been settled by a party meeting out of the House, and probably by a compromise with an opposition party meeting— Laying the whole on the table, is in fact smothering the report; but it leaves the resolutions of expulsion and of censure suspended over the heads of the members implicated— And perhaps this is the most equitable result of the whole affair that could occur.— It is a strong though indirect censure of the House upon the principals and seconds to the duel, and upon the practice itself—and it is a censure alike indirect, not less strong, and as just upon the report of the Committee, laid upon the table outrageous as it is upon every sense of impartial Justice— All the parties to the duel are severely censurable— None more so than the man
man who fell. The Majority of the Committee who presented this Report, are still more censurable, for instead of holding an impartial balance between the parties they have turned the whole subject into an electioneering engine of party.— After the decision of this day, Boon moved that twenty thousand copies of the majority report should be printed for the dear People, which the Speaker declared to be out of order— Other business followed, and I by leave reported from the Committee of Manufactures, the Senate Bill N. 176. without amendment— It was referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, and ordered to be printed— Adjourned at half past 3— I wrote the Letter to Mr Rush, for Mr Howard; and left it at his lodgings at Gadsby’s. Mr Hiland Hall and his wife paid us a visit this Evening— T. K. Davis and A. Campbell’s were also here— I retired early.
11. V:15. Friday.

Mary and Charles’s wife went with me to the Capitol, to call afterwards at Mrs Latimer’s, where Alexander H. Everett lodges to enquire how he was— He was seized yesterday morning with a pleurisy somewhat alarming but is this day better— I attended at the chamber of the Committee of manufactures a Meeting of the members of the Massachusetts delegation— Present Adams, Borden, Briggs, Calhoun, Cushing, Fletcher, Hastings, Lincoln, Parmenter, Reed. Absent Grennell and Phillips— We had each of us received printed copies of three sets of Resolutions adopted by the Legislature of Massachusetts at their late Session— One against the Sub-treasury Bill—one urging an Act of Congress against duelling, and one against the annexation of Texas to this Union.— But they are without Letter from the Governor or from the Secretary of State; and without authentication, other than that they came under a cover sealed with the Seal of the Governor and Council— On the Resolves against the annexation of Texas there is a request that they may be presented to both Houses of Congress; but not on the others. After some consultation we agreed to have an adjourned Meeting on Saturday the 19th. of this month, in the expectation of receiving some other Resolutions, which we know were adopted by the Legislature, and perhaps some further authentication of the whole— H.R.U.S. I was called out from my Seat, by the Revd. Mr Bogue; who came fromNew York, as an Agent, with a Petition in behalf of the Cherokees, which he at first asked me to present to the House, but which he afterwards said, he thought it would be best of him to ask Mr Foster, the Representative from the District whence he came to present; he therefore kept it to give it to Mr Foster, and I promised to give every aid in my power to urge it upon the consideration of the House— I told him that I had several other petitions with the same prayer, but the House would barely receive them and lay them on the table— They have already so disposed of the Cherokee memorial itself, and of the whole subject. On returning to the House I found them debating on the extra printing of the duel Committee papers— Graves had moved for the printing of 20000 copies of the testimony and Journal because a very large Edition
of the majority report had been printed and franked by the administration members— Then Fairfield moved that 20000 copies of the three reports should be printed— Whittlesey moved to reduce the number to 10000— Sampson Mason opposed the printing of an extra number altogether, on the ground that the majority report was unjust and partial, which he went on to prove with unanswerable force— The Speaker frequently interrupted him on the pretence that it was not in order to refer to the merits of the duel. Mason however persisted, disregarding the restriction of the Speaker which was wholly unwarrantable, until the expiration of the hour when Cambreleng called for the orders of the day. Mason then gave way— I asked him if he could not have insisted on continuing; as the question in debate was on the privileged subject of the duel Committee report— He said the idea had not occurred to him— At Whittlesey’s request all the Committees were called on for reports— Then Cambreleng called up the Bill to carry into effect the act of 12. October 1837 authorising an issue of treasury Notes—a false and fraudulent title— It was considered in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Ingham in the Chair— Cambreleng made a Speech of about half an hour upon the prosperous condition of the Country; the abundance of our resources; the sufficiency of our revenues; the inflexible patriotism and firmness of the administration, and the immediate indispensable necessity of furnishing the Treasury with money. He was followed by Mr Cushing in a Speech of about the same length; but whether in opposition to the Bill or not, it was not easy to say. Waddy Thompson followed in a set Speech against the Bill as unconstitutional; and urging, upon the administration a loan; though not venturing to propose one himself because it would be unpopular— Thompson had not half finished his speech when Underwood moved the Committee to rise— vote by tellers 55 to 53. No Quorum. The Committee rose, but Ingham the Chairman, reported, instead of the fact of no Quorum that they had risen without coming to any resolution— Briggs immediately moved to adjourn which was carried by yeas and nays 71 to 69. by Sherrod Williams’s changing his vote. We should else have had a fair prospect of sitting the whole Night—
12. V. Saturday.

Morning visit from Mr Cushing, with Mr Charles S. Daveis an Agent from the State of Maine, concerning the North-eastern boundary; and also concerning the shipping interest of that State going to ruin under the Treaty negotiated by Mr Van-Buren, with England— Mr Cushing said he was preparing a Report for the Committee of foreign Relations upon that subject, and upon the South-Sea boundary— Mr Daveis advised him to consult my Article in the American Quarterly Review on the trade with the British Colonies. Mr Daveis brought me a recommendatory Letter from Governor Edward Everett and I received also by the Mail a private Letter from the Governor— The two Letters are of the same date and compare curiously together. H.R.U.S. The day began with a debate, on a motion heretofore made by Mercer from the Committee of Roads and Canals to print 1500 extra copies of a survey of the Allegany river, which consumed the morning hour— Dromgoole opposed the printing, because he saw in it a covert attempt to revive the exploded
exploded system of internal improvements—the first vote taken on the printing was 46 to 52. no quorum— But Dromgoole’s resistance kindled a Spirit, under which Beatty moved to increase the number of copies from 1500 to 3000, and the order passed by yeas and nays 69 to 81. against Dromgoole’s motion to lay on the table and without yeas and nays though demanded by Rencher for the 3000 copies. Hopkins offered a joint Resolution as a substitute for the Treasury Note Bill, but the House refused to suspend the rules to receive it 69 to 107— Bell asked the suspension of the Rules to offer a Loan as a substitute—refused—82 to 94— The Treasury Note Bill was taken up in Committee of the whole, Ingham in the Chair, and debated till past midnight— Waddy Thompson finished his Speech; which was rather a vindication of his own opinions as a Southern man against John C. Calhoun’s recent apostasy, than an argument against the Bill— He was followed by R. Barnwell Rhett, in what Menefee called a volcanic eruption, and Southgate an Earthquake Speech. Rhett’s oratory is the ne plus ultra of South-Carolina rhetoric— Ranting for eloquence. Emphatic inconsistency and absurdity— He uttered a furious diatribe against the Banks— Said they were waging War against the People— They were instigating Congress to refuse the Supplies— Denied that there was any War of the Government against the Banks— Said that he was a friend to the Banks—but called them all Shylocks, and said if they did not cease to wage this War against the People, the People would pull their banking Houses down about their heads. In delivering this rhodomontade, he threw himself into convulsive attitudes reminding me of those by which Satan is said to have been discovered at the gate of Paradise, in Milton’s Poem, He was immediately answered by Menefee, and Southgate of Kentucky, in his own Style of blustering and defiance— Southgate before commencing moved that the Committee should rise, it being near 5 O’Clock, but was refused by tellers 80 to 97— Hopkins then offered Rives’s printed Bill as a substitute for that before the Committee— Cambreleng objected to this as not in order— Bell and myself contended for it as being in order, but Ingham the Chairman decided that it was not, and Hopkins did not appeal— Bell made a short Speech against the Bill, charging the Secretary of the Treasury and the Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, with presenting the State of the Treasury as far more destitute than it is— Robertson’s offered as an amendment the first Section of the Bill which Hopkins had presented, and the Chairman admitted it, as in order— From 8 in the Evening till half an hour after Midnight, the time was consumed by W. Cost Johnson and Harper of Ohio, speaking against time, with motions at intervals of about ten minutes for the Committee to rise, always failing by the casting vote of the Chairman, or by majorities of one or two votes—several times with a majority of one for rising; balanced by the vote of the Chairman making a tie, and thus defeating the motion— When Midnight came Governor Pope made it a point of Order, whether the Committee should continue in Session on the Sabbath, and moved the Committee to rise, to take the question of adjournment by yeas and nays— Ingham read from the Journals of 1836. the precedent of the case when Lawler made the same point of order; and as Lawler had then withdrawn his appeal, Ingham decided that it was in order to legislate, on the Sabbath, from which decision Pope took an Appeal— The vote on Pope’s motion to rise was 83
83. to 82. The Chairman voted in the negative, made a tie and declared that the Committee had refused to rise— Pope made an argument of delivery with him, and said that as it was a vote upon an appeal, from the Chairman’s decision, he ought not himself to vote— Underwood contended that as it was an appeal on a point of order from the decision of the Chairman, and as the statement of the question must be, shall the decision stand, as the opinion of the Committee, it must be carried by a positive majority, and the Chairman’s tie could not affirm his decision, but affirmed the vote of the Committee to rise— At last Morgan of Virginia, rose and said he was convinced it would be useless longer to struggle to come this night to a conclusion, and he moved the Committee should rise— Two or three votes were changed— The Committee rose, and the motion to adjourn was carried by yeas and nays 85 to 72. 5 minutes before One O’Clock Sunday Morning— Mr Cambreleng took a seat with me in my Carriage, and I took him to his lodgings— I had taken nothing but a glass of water since breakfast— After a warm cup of Shells, and a slice of bread and butter, I reached my bed just before two.
13. VII— Sunday

My Son and my three Granddaughters went with me this morning to the Presbyterian Church, where we heard a young man, a Stranger, from John 5.40. “And ye will not come to me, that ye might have life.” He read a notice for another Meeting of the Church and Congregation, to-morrow afternoon, to consider of means for the future support of their Pastor.— We had all been invited to dine this day with Mr Thomas Baker Johnson, at his present residence with Kervand at Woodley; in Maryland, beyond the heights of Georgetown— Mr Pope called at our house in a Carriage between two and three O’Clock— Charles and myself took Seats with him— My wife, with Mary, Mrs Charles and Isaac Hull went in our Carriage— We dined with Mr Johnson, and came home at the dusk of Evening— Woodley is about 5 miles from our house, and was formerly the residence of Philip Barton Key, a native of Maryland, once an Officer in a Refugee Corps in the British army during the revolutionary War, and afterwards a member of the House of Representatives of the United States— He came into the House in 1807 His election was contested on two grounds—first that he was not an inhabitant of the District in Maryland for which he was chosen—and secondly that he was a half pay British Officer— Woodley is in the District of Columbia— But he had a house in the adjoining County of Montgomery in Maryland, where he occasionally resided— The House confirmed him in his Seat, and he represented the District in several successive Congresses— The house is now in a somewhat dilapidated condition and until recently taken by Kervand had been long uninhabited— The trees are not yet in full foliage, but for the first time this Season I observed a Horse-chesnut tree, studded with its white plumes.
14. VI. Monday.

Met the Committee of Manufactures at 1/2 past 9. Present Adams, Foster, Naylor, Slade, Tillinghast, Webster— Absent Biddle, Hunter, Vail. The Memorial of James Goddard and others of the Macon Steam-boat company, for leave to import free of duties iron for two iron steam-boats was considered, and postponed till the meeting next Thursday. H.R.U.S.
H.R.U.S— Boon of Indiana, acting as he said under Instructions from his Constituents asked leave to offer a Resolution, that from and after the 1st. of June next there shall be no discrimination in the kind or description of currency receivable by the Government for customs, for the sale of the public Lands, or for any debt or duty due or owing to the United States— On examination it was found that there was already before the House a Resolution to the same effect offered some time since by Mr Bond. He withdrew it, and Boon’s motion to suspend the rules was lost by yeas and nays 95 to 53 for want of a vote of two thirds— It was the bi-weekly day for receiving Resolutions, but Cambreleng moved a suspension of the Rules to go into Committee of the whole upon the state of the Union, on the Treasury Note Bill—carried 132 to 50— Harper resumed the floor from Sunday Morning and concluded his Speech against the Bill— He was followed by Hawes of Kentucky, a brother of the member of the last Congress, who commenced a regular-built Maiden Speech, but was taken ill with a fainting fit, from which however he soon recovered, and was taken home to his lodgings. Dunn of Indiana took his place, and was followed by Goode of Ohio, and he, by John Sergeant, who brought Cambreleng’s currency Report to the experimentum crucis—and re-inforced the argument against the Bill— Then came Tillinghast, who spoke till near seven O’Clock, with repeated intervals for motions to adjourn, all lost, counting by Tellers, and by majorities of 4 or 5 votes— At last Robertson moved to adjourn, giving a sort of promise for the opposition, that the bill should be reported to the House to-morrow, and subject to the previous Question after 4. P.M. on Wednesday— On this pledge the motion to rise was carried 91 to 86. and the motion to adjourn, with refusal of the yeas and nays, demanded by Bronson, succeeded by a vote of 85 to 73— I walked home, and found at my door a Mr Cogswell, who claimed old acquaintance with me, being a teacher of some School in Massachusetts— I took a slight repast and went to the Theatre where my family were already and where we heard and saw the Opera of the Somnambula, Madame Caradori-Allan performing the part of Amina— The House was crowded— The President, and his Cabinet Ministers there— Many members of both Houses of Congress— My wife—Mary Charles and his wife, Isaac Hull Adams and his friend Campbell formed our party— After this play a young Bayadere, named Miss Lee exhibited some saltatorial distortions, which were more applauded than all the Caradori warblings, which were delicious— We did not stay to the after-piece, which was the American Tar— It was past 11. O’Clock when we came home, and my wife went to bed—extremely ill with her cough—paying dear as she said for her little frolic.— We had been invited to the Wedding party of Miss Sperry.
15. V:30. Tuesday

My dear wife was so excessively ill with a threatened croup, in the Night, that I was obliged to call up Mrs Goods, to administer to her an emetic which afforded her but partial relief— We were up great part of the Night, and I
I had scarcely one hour of repose— Yet I was engaged to meet at half past 9 O’Clock this morning the Committee on Meteorology of which John Sergeant is Chairman— I attended accordingly at the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures; but no one came— Sergeant had forgotten it himself, and forgotten to give notice to the other members of the Committee— H.R.U.S. a Report was received from the Secretary of the Navy, in answer to my resolution calling for returns of payments in advance to Agents, which at my motion was laid on the table, and ordered to be printed— Sundry reports from Committees were received— Boon renewed his motion to suspend the rules to receive his Resolution against any discrimination of currency in the receipt of public monies— Sherrod Williams had offered a similar Resolution on the 16th. of April—which though only for an instruction to the Committee of Ways and Means, the Speaker decided to be the same with that of Boon, which was a joint Resolution— The question for suspension of the rules therefore was to take up Williams’s Resolution, and was lost by yeas and nays, 94 to 76. not two thirds— Boon gave notice that he should renew his motion every day till the House should act upon it— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Ingham in the Chair on the Treasury Note Bill— Tillinghast concluded his Speech against the Bill. Cushman gave a sneaking and disingenuous explanation of the base intrigue in the first weeks of Jackson’s administration to displace Jeremiah Mason as President of the U.S. Branch Bank at Portsmouth, New-Hampshire; and to palm upon the Bank a whole board of Directors of that Branch at the nomination of Isaac Hill, Levi Woodbury and a gang of Jackson members of the New-Hampshire Legislature— Cushman was himself one of the persons thus recommended for Directors of the Branch— He has been ever since and is now one of Isaac Hill’s edge-tools— Richard Biddle followed in a Speech against the Bill, of about an hour and a half, the most eloquent that has been made on the subject— Bell of Tennessee succeeded, and then Randolph of New-Jersey, his first long premeditated Speech, more remarkable for consuming time than for attracting attention— It was irresistibly dull, though the Orator is gifted with a clear, strong, and well-toned voice— The Committee were so weary of the subject, that Mr Randolph had few if any listeners— Night was coming on, and after sundry attempts to make the Committee rise, which failed, just before 8 in the Evening by general agreement they rose and reported the Bill, without deciding upon any of the amendments, proposed; but with the understanding that they should all be printed, to be ready for discussion to morrow morning upon the Bill, in the House. I gave notice that if the Bill should pass in its present shape I should move an amendment to its title—to strike out the words to carry into effect the Act of the 12th. of October 1837— The House rose at 8. I walked home, and found Mrs Adams in bed, but much recovered— She had been copiously bled this morning— The rest of the family were already at the Theatre, where after a light meal I joined them— The play was Rossinis Barber of Seville, Madame Caradori-Allan performing the part of Rosina— It was about half over when I got in— Mrs W. S. Smith was there in the place of my wife— Mary, Charles and his wife, and Isaac Hull Adams were the party— The House as full as it could hold— Brough sung a song after the Opera; and Miss Lee danced— We did not stay to the after piece, which was no Song no Supper— It was past 11. when we got home, and I was thoroughly weary.
16. VI. Wednesday.

The state of my health is deeply affected by the length of my days— Relief more or less, for a single day from infirmities, increasing from week to week, and from month to month, is all that I can henceforth expect, for the short remnant of my days— The hours of yesterday hung heavy upon my hands— This day was more supportable.— H.R.U.S.— Boon renewed his motion to suspend the Rules, for the consideration of Sherrod Williams’s Resolution, which Williams declared his assent to turn from an instruction to the Committee of Ways and Means, into a joint Resolution— On a call for the yeas and nays, no Quorum appearing Briggs moved a call of the House which was commenced, but suspended before it was gone through— The yeas and nays for the suspension of the Rules were 111 to 70. a large majority, but not two thirds. A Resolution from the Senate for the Relief of Vespasian Ellis, passed through its three readings at the urgency of H. A. Wise, who was named in it and had some agency in the transaction to which it applied— After some other business of Routine, the Rules on Cambreleng’s motion were suspended and the Treasury Note Bill, reported last Night to the House was taken up. Cambreleng moved an amendment referring additionally to the act of 12. October 1837. Robertson’s amendment, proposing a loan as a substitute for the Treasury Notes, and a further amendment proposing a loan, together with an issue of 2. Millions of Treasury Notes were before the House for Consideration— Ogden Hoffman began the debate with a speech of great heat, chiefly in answer to Rhett, and South Carolina Nullification— But as Hoffman touched upon the sore of South-Carolina, Waddy Thompson against whom Rhett’s speech had been chiefly pointed, felt himself bound to defend his State in reply to Thompson— John W. Jones of Virginia, followed with a moderate and sensible Speech in support of the Bill— Jones is a member of the Committee of Ways and Means—a lame and mean looking man; seldom speaking, though a very handsome speaker, and covering under a cold exterior of indifference a deep and rancorous malignity— Wise succeeded him, in a Speech of not much impression, because he has been a week absent, and had taken no time for premeditation. He exhibited an old continental bill for 30 dollars of May 1775—and a sheet of North-Carolina 5 and 10 dollar Bills of 1778. and compared them with the Treasury Notes, issued under the Act of 12. Octr. 1837. Bynum came next with an effusion of his oil of vitriol for about two hours. Evening was coming on— Garland of Louisiana moved to adjourn; but on opposition made withdrew the motion, afterwards renewed by Calhoun and rejected by yeas and nays 64 to 125. Cushman then moved the previous question— There was a call of the House till the presence of 200 members was ascertained— The vote seconding the previous question was 98 to 95— That ordering the main question 99 to 99. a tie—carried by the casting vote of the Speaker— The vote to engross the Bill was 106. to 99— The Virginia conservatives and Rariden of Indiana voting for it— Sherrod Williams moved to recommit the Bill with Instructions to Report a Loan, Treasury Notes and the sale of the Bonds of the Bank of the United States. Cushman moved again the previous question carried 103 to 94. Rariden moved a reconsideration of the engrossment of the Bill; which the Speaker against the Remonstrances of Mr Bell pronounced not in order— The Bill was then passed without taking the yeas and nays. I
I moved to strike out from the title, the words “to carry into effect the act approved the 12th. of October 1837.” which was agreed to: and Mr Fletcher moved to add the words, “to meet the current expenses of the Government.” which was also agreed to. Rariden then gave notice that he should to-morrow move the reconsideration of the vote on the passage of the Bill— At a quarter past ten in the Evening the House adjourned— I walked home, and after slight refreshment went to bed— My wife being yet confined there— Mary, Charles and his wife, and Isaac Hull Adams were spending the Evening at Mr Frye’s—a party to which Mr Pope and I were invited—but from which we were detained by the Session of the House through the Evening.

div.p: 17. VI. Thursday.

Committee of Manufactures— Present Adams, Foster, Naylor, Slade, Tillinghast, Webster— Absent, Biddle, Hunter Vail— The Chairman was directed to prepare Bills to authorise James Goddard and the Macon Steamboat Company to import free of duty iron for two Steam-boats, and to refund duties paid upon the importation of iron by the GeorgiaCompany— The Memorial of William Colgate and others, praying for a duty of 5 cents per lb on imported Starch was read and postponed— There is a bill reported in the Senate for levying a duty of 2 cents per lb on Starch— A Bill which cannot constitutionally originate in the Senate. H.R.U.S. Immediately after the reading of the Journal, Rariden rose to move the reconsideration of the vote on the passage of the Treasury Note Bill—but the Speaker said it must lie over till the expiration of the morning hour.— and that the first question must be on Mr Lincoln’s motion to print 10,000 extra copies of a report from the Committee on the militia— Russell of New-York moved a suspension of the rules to introduce a Resolution instructing the Committee of ways and means to enquire into the expediency of repealing the restrictions on the receipt of the Bills of Banks which issue small Bills— The vote upon the suspension of the rules was by yeas and nays 56 to 126. upon which Russell gave notice that he should renew the motion every day, till the House should act upon it— Mr Cushman moved a suspension of the Rules for half an hour to take up a bill for the appointment of persons to test the usefulness of certain inventions to prevent the explosion of Steam-boat boilers—but failed— Boon made his daily motion for rescinding the Specie Circular, with no better success— Sundry reports were received—one from the Post Office Committee, of a Bill from the Senate directing the Postmaster General to settle a claim of Hard and Longstreet, upon principles of equity and Justice; which it was attempted to force through the house at once— I asked what was the occasion for the Bill; which gave rise to sundry explanations from Briggs, Legare and Waddy Thompson, but Underwood opposed the immediate passage of the Bill, and Cambreleng called for the orders of the day— Rariden’s motion for reconsideration then came up— Several questions of ordered were proposed and adjusted— A call of the House ordered, and carried through till 215 members answered to their names—the previous question seconded by a vote of 119. and the main question ordered 141 to 64— The vote on reconsideration was 110 to 109. The Speaker voted in the negative making a tie— So the reconsideration was not carried and the bill was passed— If the vote had been direct on the passage of the Bill, it would thus have been rejected— Jones and Downing the Delegates from the Territories of Wisconsin and Florida moved and carried a suspension
suspension of the rules, and a Resolution fixing Tuesday and Wednesday the 5th. and 6th. of June for the consideration of Bills, relating to the Territories. There was a Message from the President relating to the title of the United States to the Territory West of the Rocky Mountains— Mr Cushing had moved the Resolution calling for it; and then a Resolution referring it to the Committee of Foreign Relations with instructions to enquire into the expediency of establishing a post on the Columbia river for the defence thereof, and of making further provision by law to prevent any intermedling by any foreign power with the Indians there. Mr Cushing made a Speech tracing the history of the disputed titles to the Northwest Coast and of our Negotiations with Great Britain concerning it; and he alledged that Great-Britain had been encroaching upon our rights there as she had been on the North-eastern boundary. He laid down certain positions somewhat questionable concerning territorial rights in this Western Hemisphere; and called very emphatically upon me to sustain him both with regard to his facts and his principles— Thus suddenly called out, I took the floor, and rambled over the topics upon which he had touched, for an hour or more, without order or method; as kind and courteous to him as I could be, and dissatisfied with no one but myself— Rice Garland came, and intreated me to write out and publish my speech on account of what I had said concerning West Florida— After I had finished, Cushing soon gave way to a motion for adjournment which was carried about 4. O’Clock— There was not half a Quorum in the House— I came home thoroughly wearied and worn out.
18. VI. Friday

H.R.U.S. This day, the first for several weeks was devoted by the House to the consideration of private business; and of course almost all with less than a Quorum of the Members present— Many reports from Committees upon cases of claims were received. The Bill directing the Postmaster General to settle the account of Hard, and Longstreet was driven through, notwithstanding Underwood’s continued opposition— I sunk into Silence— Two or three Bills for establishing Pension agencies in several States, crept along without much notice— This business was heretofore every where transacted gratuitously by the Bank of the United States— The Pension agency now are a considerable charge, and established without concert of system. There was debate between Fletcher and Allen of Vermont, whether the Pension-agency proposed to be established in that State should be at Burlington or at Montpelier.— Governor Lincoln reported a Bill relating to the public buildings, and made an earnest effort to prevail upon the House to take up the Bill to provide for the removal of the Walls of the new Treasury Building, and for the erection of a fireproof building for the Post-Office Department— Numbers of workmen, depending with their families for their daily subsistence upon employment, have been discharged for want of the passage of this Bill— Three or four of them stopped me a few days since, in the passage way to the House, and represented to me their destitute condition— The Speaker said he had a memorial from a number of them which he had been requested to present— Sergeant made an appeal to the House in their favour— Lincoln moved to suspend the rules to go into Committee of the whole on the Bill at Noon this day, but the motion was rejected by yeas and nays 70 to 99. Boon
Boon and Russell consented severally to dispense for this day, with their daily motion to suspend the Rules— Cambreleng said there were 600000 dollars of drafts on the Quartermaster’s department under protest, and moved to go into Committee of the whole on the public business; but the House refused— He then gave notice that he should make the same motion next Monday, after the reception of Petitions— The House then went into Committee of the whole, Atherton in the Chair, upon 33 private Bills; all of which were reported, some without and some with amendments, and on some progress, and leave to sit again a clause in perhaps two thirds of the Bills, allowing long interest upon antiquated claims was after some discussion stricken out from them all— It had been stubbornly debated on former days— It was now reluctantly yielded—to save the original claims themselves— Mr. Whittlesey was very anxious to go into Committee again; but the members in attendance were too much wearied with their drudgery and the House adjourned before 5. I returned the English Translation of Hennepin’s book to the Library; for Mr Fillmore, who had applied for it.— Sultry.
19. V:30. Saturday.

Mr Frye had called yesterday, and informed me that Easby’s work at the Milldam was half-finished, and according to the contract, I gave him a check upon the Bank of Washington for 550 dollars— Adjourned Meeting of the Members of the Massachusetts delegation, at the Chamber of the Committee of Manufactures— Present Adams, Borden, Briggs, Calhoun, Cushing, Fletcher, Grennell, Hastings, Lincoln, Parmenter, Reed— Only Phillips absent, as he has been, many weeks— Each of us had received ten sets of Resolves adopted by the Legislature of Massachusetts at their late Session— 1. Against the annexation of Texas 2. Subtreasury. 3. Right of Petition 4. North-eastern boundary 5. Slavery and Slave-trade in the District of Columbia and Territories 6. Admission of New States 7. Inter-State Slave trade— 8. Militia. 9. Relations with Indian Tribes. 10. Duelling— These were all printed Papers without authentication— Governor Lincoln said he had written to the Secretary of the State Mr John P. Bigelow to enquire how this had happened— Mr Cushing said he had also written to the Governor making the same enquiry. and had received from him an answer; that it was by inadvertence and would be rectified— Governor Lincoln was averse to presenting any of these Resolutions to the House, till they shall be duly authenticated; but as there was a confident expectation that they would be so by the Mail of this or of to-morrow Evening, it was agreed that on Monday next, each of us should present one set of the Resolutions; and they were distributed among the members of the Delegation—there being one set for each member excepting one— The moving for the disposal of them was left to the discretion of each presenting member— H.R.U.S. Linn Banks, took his Seat in the House as the successor of John M. Patton— Cambreleng presented a communication from the acting Secretary of War, with very urgent calls for money from the Quarter Master General— Governor Lincoln renewed the attempt to have Monday fixed for taking up the Bill to remove the Walls of the Treasury Building; but the yeas and nays were called and the motion was rejected 67 to 77. Russell made his daily motion to suspend the Rules for a Resolution to repeal the Law against the reception of Bills of Banks, that issue small bills: the suspension was refused 53 to 101. Boon also repeated his motion for
for leave to offer a Resolution to annul the Specie Circular—lost for want of two thirds by a vote of 108. to 63— The annual document of Commerce and Navigation was received from the Secretary of the Treasury, and laid before the House by the Speaker— Elisha Whittlesey moved the printing of 10000 copies— Harlan proposed to reduce the number to 5000. Whittlesey insisted, and I put in a word of the same exhortation—the 10000 copies were ordered— The Bill for establishing a Pension agency at M’Minnville Tennessee, was after some debate rejected 44 to 89— A motion to adjourn was rejected by yeas and nays 46 to 56—no Quorum— Then a call of the House moved by E. Whittlesey, was refused 40 to 47. and then the House adjourned about 3. without dividing— I went into the Library and took out La Salle’s last Voyage; journalized by Joutel— A man by the name of Fowler came, and told me that he was a professor of Phrenology, and wished to take a fac-simile of my face and head— I promised to call upon him at Elliot’s buildings next Tuesday morning.— I received this evening circulars signed by Governor Edward Everett and by John P. Bigelow Secretary of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, authenticating the ten sets of Resolutions of the Legislature, previously received— Also a Letter from Benjamin Lundy, announcing the destruction by fire kindled by a mob of the new Pennsylvania Hall, erected expressly for free discussion which had been opened lastIt was the Night before last— Thursday 17. May 1838 burnt to the ground— Lundy says that all the valuable property that he had in the world was deposited there and is destroyed.
20. V. Sunday.

I struggle in vain to redeem arrears of Diary and Correspondence, and to keep in order my files of Letters and of Petitions— This morning at the Presbyterian Church I heard Mr Gurley from Job 28.12. “But where shall wisdom be found? and where is the place of understanding?” What a Sermon might be written upon this text! That of Mr Gurley was calm, sensible and cold— Mrs Frye was here after morning service but did not stay— Thomas Frye, and Miss Johnston, dined with us— After dinner, Mr Hawley at St. John’s Church, read the Evening service for the 5th. Sunday after Easter, and preached from 2. Samuel 7.18. “Then went king David in, and sat before the Lord, and he said, who am I, O Lord God, and what is my house, that thou hast brought me hitherto? 19. And this was yet a small thing in thy sight, O Lord God; but thou hast spoken also of thy servant’s house for a great while to come. And is this the manner of man, O Lord God?” Mr Hawley’s discourse was chiefly a commentary upon the words “and is this the manner of man[”]— The building of the Temple at Jerusalem, is among the most remarkable events in the History of the Jews— And is to be considered under various aspects— It was a Church— Why should such transcendant importance have been attached to the building of a Church? Temples innumerable had been long before built to the heathen Gods in all the surrounding Countries?— In this 7th. Chapter of the second Book of Samuel, the project of building a Temple is stated as having casually occurred to David after he had conquered his enemies, and had
had built a Palace for himself— He consults the prophet Nathan who at first approves the design; but receives the same Night a command from the Lord to go and tell David not to build the Temple, but that his Son shall build it, and that the kingdom shall be established in his, David’s family forever. In the 17th. chapter of the first book of Chronicles this narrative is repeated—and in both places the reason assigned for the interdict is, that from the time of the delivery of the Law upon Sinai, the Lord had never commanded that a House should be built for him— But in the 22d. chapter of 1. Chronicles v. 8. David says that the reason assigned by the Lord for forbidding him to build the temple was that he had been a man of War, and had shed blood—which he repeats in the same Book. Chapter 28 v. 3. in his address to the People, on declaring his Son Solomon their king.— Why is it that the reason assigned to the prophet Nathan, and by him reported to David, so essentially differs from that twice stated by David to have been revealed to himself? Was it that the divine communication to Nathan, was not complete? That the divine purpose was to spare David the mortification of hearing from his subject, a reason for refusing his intended act of homage, which implied displeasure, and disapprobation of his conduct— And throughout all the Scriptures, is there a more tender and sublime admonition, to kings and rulers of men, to cultivate peace, and to hold human blood precious and inviolable, than this prohibition of Almighty God, to the man after his own heart, to build him a temple, because he had been a warrior—a shedder of blood?— But I have no time for a Dissertation upon the Temple—
21. V:30 Monday

Attended at the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, at 1/2 past 9, but the only other member who attended there, was Mr Slade, and of course we could do no business— H.R.U.S— The States beginning with Maine were called for Petitions; of which I presented 35 being exactly the number of days since the last presentation— 24 of these were against that abomination the fraudulent Treaty of New Echota, and for justice and mercy to the Cherokee Indians— I presented them all at once, knowing that every one of them would be separately laid upon the table— Multitudes of other Petitions to the same effect were thus laid on the table at the motion of the members from Georgia— Calvary Morris afterwards presented one from 177 citizens of Marietta, Ohio, which with a short Speech he moved should be referred to a select Committee— Owens moved it should be laid on the table— Morris called for the yeas and nays— Chapman of Alabama moved a call of the House, but it was denied, and the Petition was laid on the Table 107 to 71— I presented the petition of Stephen Toller and 30 inhabitants of Jeffersonville, Goochland Co. Virginia, praying for my expulsion, as a nuisance, which I moved should be referred to the Committee on the judiciary— Dromgoole said he supposed it was a Quiz—or if not; it was a question of privilege, and must be decided by the House— He moved it should be laid on the Table unless the Gentlemen from Massachusetts wished to give it another direction. I said the Gentleman from Massachusetts cared very little about it—and it was laid on
on the table— Of the Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts those concerning the Militia were presented by Govr. Lincoln, and referred to the Committee of the Whole on the state of the Union—those on the Subtreasury Bill, to the Committee of Ways and Means—presented by Mr Fletcher— Those on the North-eastern boundary, by Mr Cushing; referred to the Committee of the whole, upon George Evans’s Bill— Those on our Indian Relations by Mr Reed, and at the motion of a Georgia member laid on the table— They objected also to their being printed—and that question was laid over. Those against the annexation of Texas were presented by George N. Briggs, who moved their reference to the Committee of foreign Relations, and that they be printed— Haynes was just moving to lay them on the table, when I appealed to his candour; and generosity and also to his State rights principles, to let them be referred; observing that I hoped and trusted the questions relating to Texas and Mexico, would now cease to be causes of division, among us— That the Mexican proposal for an arbitration of our differences has been accepted. That the Texian proposal for annexation has been, or is about to be withdrawn— That all objection to a fair consideration of these Memorials and Petitions seemed to be removed; and the Gentleman from Georgia, might be well assured that no report from the Committee of Foreign Relations on this subject, unfriendly to his views was to be expected— Haynes then said that to shew his generosity since I appealed to it, he would withdraw his objection to the reference and the printing of these Resolutions— No other person made objection and the Resolutions were referred this point being gained I moved the reference to the same Committee of all the petitions this day presented against the annexation of Texas; of which there were several— Some uneasiness was manifested by several members, and particularly by C. F. Mercer, who objected to the reference of one Memorial, but upon being told by the Speaker that several had been referred withdrew his objection, not without muttering.— W. C. Calhoun presented the Massachusetts Legislative Resolution against the admission of any new Slave State into the Union— The first Resolution was half read, until the clerk came to the word Slavery, when he was stop’d by the Speaker, and the Resolutions were laid on the table under the order of 21. Decr. 1837.— Grennell presented the Resolutions on the subject of duelling which were referred to the Committee of the whole House on the state of the Union, to which the Bill from the Senate against duelling has been referred. There remain three sets of Resolutions of the Massachusetts Legislature to be presented hereafter— Among the petitions which I presented was one with documents which I found on my table, from Lianah Kibbey for a widows pension— The Speaker presented several petitions, and I reminded him of one from the workmen employed here on the public buildings thrown out of employment by the suspension of the work on the Treasury building— He presented it, and it was referred to the Committee on the Public buildings After the call for Petitions was gone through, Boon had leave to make an explanation; which was that he and Sherrod Williams had disagreed as to the mode and form in which the Resolution against the Specie circular was to be brought forward, and so he had no alternative but
but to resume his Seat— The Bill making appropriations for the suppression of Indian hostilities (nearly 6. Millions) was taken up in Committee of the whole. Howard in the Chair, and after some discussion and amendments proposed by Cambreleng, Everett and Wise, the Committee rose—the Bill authorising the appointment of an additional judge of the Orphans Count for the County of Washington in the District of Columbia passed to a third reading, and passed as it came from the Senate— An Amendment had been proposed by the District Committee, that the tenure of Office of the additional judge should be limited to four years— The incumbent is superannuated and incompetent the amendment was rejected— Mr Pope struggled hard to prevail on the House to take up and pass a Bill for the relief of the widow of Captain Thomas Hunter—but it was impossible to keep a Quorum—and the House adjourned near 5. There was a regatta or boat-race at the Navy yard, succeeded by a dancing party—Mary, Charles and his wife, and Isaac Hull were invited to it— All excepting Hull came home immediately after the race— He stayed to the dance and came home shortly before Midnight— Visits from Messrs. Taliaferro Whittlesey and Metcalfe—
